info.name: memory streched Perlin
info.description:
bottom: no noise stretching.
top: global noise stretching.
middle: the higher the wavelength, the more stretch. 
Interpretation: larger phenomema are often slower: deformation has time to act. Small ones are often fast and just born and thus less distort

renderpass.code:
void mainImage( out vec4 O, vec2 u )
{
    vec2 R = iResolution.xy,
         U = u / R.y /16. + vec2(.002*iTime,0),
         S, T = vec2(0); // vec2(.01*iTime,0);
    mat2 rot = mat2(cos( 2. + vec4(0,1.5708,-1.5708,0))), M = rot;

    int y = int(3.*u.y/R.y);                // panel id
    float N = 7.,                           // amount of details
          k = exp2(-N), e, v = 0., w = -.2*sign(iMouse.z-1.) ;
    
    for (float i=0.; i<N; i++, k*=2.)       // Perlin fractal cascade
        S = vec2( pow( 1.4, y==0 ? 0. : y==1 ? -i : -N ) ,1 ),       // stretching
        v += abs(2.* texture(iChannel0, (U/k-T) *S *M ).x -1. ) * k, // base noise
        M *= rot;                           // to avoid grid-aligned artifacts
    
    v = smoothstep(-w,w, v-.37);            // shaping function
    O = vec4( pow(v,1./2.2) );              // to sRGB
    if (int(3.*(u.y-.5))%int(R.y)<2) O-=O,O.r++; // separator
}
renderpass.name: Image
